Description: A hollow terracotta head broken from a figure of a female beneficent demon, with rows of curls around the face and the hair drawn back in V-shaped parallel lines with a central groove at the back. The ears are pierced. She wears two close-fitting necklets. Two-piece mould. Orange-brown Nile silt, with a little mica, and a darker brown surface. Traces overall of a white dressing.
Curator's comments: Made in Roman Egypt during the second century AD. (Bailey 2008, 48, pl. 20). Comparanda (heads and complete figures) include very close examples from the Allard Pierson Museum (Amsterdam, no. 7468), and the Ashmolean Museum (Oxford, no. 1966.1060). Also close parallels from Karanis (Allen 1985, nos 82 and 83), dated mid-first to second century AD or later, from Middle Egypt, dated first century AD (Besques 1992, no. E 392), and dated first half of third century AD (Castiglione 1969, pl. 89). Similar parallels include alien head dated second half of third century AD (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, no. 261; also no. 307), example dated second to third century AD (Dewachter 1986: 85, no. 103; Bonham's 'Sale Catalogue', 7 October 1997, lot 338), from House H at Herakleopolis Magna, dated fourth century AD (Petrie 1905, pl. l:96; Petrie and Currelly 1905, 4, 27; Bailey 2008, 48 dates this to second to fourth century AD; Török 1995, nos 174–7; Weber 1914, no. 226).
